comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Wonderful picture.  Any clues as to date?  I'd say very early 1900s, but not really clear

comment.author: 33605249@N02
comment._content: Looks like the same leather summer sandals which we wore in the UK in the 1950's. You can just see the single metal buckle fastening on the outer side. Apparently this "T-bar" shape gradually became girls-only in the 1970's - while boys favoured the later enclosed shape more like a shoe. Memory confirmation courtesy of histclo.com/schun/gar/shoe/sandal/su-sandalest.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: See: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3251833363/in/pho... for more information. I think it is about 1895 in Melbourne, and this is Louis Frederick (b1890) and Alexander (b.1893) McCubbin, the sons of Frederick McCubbin, famous Australian artist. @ richard halliday (see note above) - Louis went on to become the Director of the Art Gallery in South Australia. Another brother Hugh (the baby in the other picture, b.1894) was wounded at Gallipoli in 1915. And, by the way, I too had red leather sandals like those in the early 1960s in England, made by Clarks. I hated them then - they did feel 'girly' - yuk!

comment.author: 33332513@N03
comment._content: This is an extremely intriguing and beautiful photo. The 'print' has been really well-done.

comment.author: 70313510@N00
comment._content: The boy's shoes look like "Startrite" brand sandals - or a precursor.  These were unisex kids shoes with a soft leather upper and crepe rubber sole.  As the name implies, they were supposed to have health benefits, letting your foot grow naturally etc etc.

comment.author: 32465819@N05
comment._content: I would say, by the looks of the clothing, and the shoes, that the above dating would be fairly right on. They still sell shoes like these in England and Ireland ... France too. They're known as t-strap, teardrop, and/or barefoot sandals. I have four pair in my collection, one of which is posted below (the soles would have been leather then, rather than crepe, but the design hasn't changed much in over a hundred years). Have as well, a blue-gray linen nautical style suit much like the older boy's in the photo, and a tricycle like the younger tot's ... and it does look seriously uncomfortable! Wonderful, well preserved glass plate image.
